channel.title: Expansionism on Ecological Foodways
channel.description: Recent content in Expansionism on Ecological Foodways

item.title: poke sallet
item.description: “… probably the best known and most widely used wild vegetable in America.” Euell Gibbons (needs verification) Characteristics, Ecology, History Phytolacca americana Phytolaccin Native to North America (also possibly found in Africa) Appalachian staple Associated with poor, rural south (e.g. “Poke Salad Annie”) Exported to Europe as an ornamental Used by the Algonquin for dye Civil War Era Letters possibly written in Pokeberry ink Pigeon Berry Eaten in large quantities by passenger pigeons

item.title: Sugar cane and the southern influence on Pacific Imperialism
item.description: Sugar Cane Sugar was the driving force in colonization of the New World, the dominance of Great Britain in the West Indies In the South and the North, sugar was a highly lucrative industry that drove slave trade Sugar cane was the primary food that drove land conversion and industry in Hawaii A group of American entrepreneurs and missionaries who were largely built on sugar interests eventually orchestrated significant blows to the Hawaii monarchy This included the Reciprocity Treaty, which opened Hawaiian sugar markets to the US, and the Bayonett Treaty, including the abdication of Queen Lili’o’kalani Queen Lili’o’kalani contested her abdication and with support from the Clevland Administration, a former confederate, southern democratic senator, James H.

item.title: Sugar cane and the southern influence on Pacific Imperialism
item.description: Sugar Cane Sugar was the driving force in colonization of the New World, the dominance of Great Britain in the West Indies In the South and the North, sugar was a highly lucrative industry that drove slave trade Sugar cane was the primary food that drove land conversion and industry in Hawaii A group of American entrepreneurs and missionaries who were largely built on sugar interests eventually orchestrated significant blows to the Hawaii monarchy This included the Reciprocity Treaty, which opened Hawaiian sugar markets to the US, and the Bayonett Treaty, including the abdication of Queen Lili’o’kalani Queen Lili’o’kalani contested her abdication and with support from the Clevland Administration, a former confederate, southern democratic senator, James H.
